jamesmisc 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values)

remove_na_cols.Rd

This function takes a data frame and automatically removes the columns that only contain NA values. Also, the user can set a desired threshold for removing columns with a proportion of NA values exceeding that threshold.

Usage

remove_na_cols(data, threshold = 1)

Arguments

data

A data frame or tibble. If there are NA-only columns, they will be removed, though it isn't necessary for data to have NA-only columns.

threshold

A numeric between 0 and 1. Default is 1 (i.e., 100%). Represents the threshold proportion of NA values if the user wants to remove columns that are not purely NA, but whose proportion of NA values exceeds the specified threshold.

Value

Your data frame, minus the columns that were removed

Examples

# Remove columns that are NA-only
library(dplyr)

mtcars$drat <- NA_real_
mtcars_new <- mtcars %>% remove_na_cols()
mtcars_new
#>                      mpg cyl  disp  hp    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
#> Mazda RX4           21.0   6 160.0 110 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
#> Mazda RX4 Wag       21.0   6 160.0 110 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4

# Set a threshold proportion of NA values for column-removal
library(dplyr)

mtcars$drat <- NA_real_
mtcars %>%
  mutate(drat = case_when(mpg > 31 ~ 3.5)) %>%
  remove_na_cols(threshold = .93) # Change threshold to .94 and drat will remain
